I studied chemistry for 4 years. Here’s my takeaway:

The difference between electromagnetic energy and micro radiation is they both do not cause cancer. Colors are correlated to wave lengths which cannot penetrate through DNA or solid surfaces. If you stand close to a microwave it will not damage chromosomes or your DNA. Also the colour of visible light depends on its wavelength. These wavelengths range from 700 nm at the red end of the spectrum to 400 nm at the violet end. Visible light waves are the only electromagnetic waves we can see. And just to emphasize, Ionizing radiation mostly comes from radioactive sources. Several kinds of ionizing radiation will cause DNA damage. But for example: microwaves are not radioactive, and do not cause ionizing radiation. Another myth about microwaves is that they penetrate to the bone which is not true.

For people like me, it'd help a lot if we were listening as I'd easily ask anyone to just turn the airplane's mode on and off at random interval without telling me. If I could tell when the phone switch to airplane to normal mode with accuracy a few times in a row, then I'd know it is not my imagination and I'd reach a student in search for a thesis. Here's a counter-point that has nothing to do with the health effects: Why do we need faster stronger internet connection? So that corporations can get more data out of you and show you more ads. 3g was good enough until the bandwidth got clogged with junk, so we got 4g, which also was good enough until it got clogged with even more junk.

Websites that forego sending and receiving unnecessary junk are in most cases way faster than they need to be and just adding an ad-blocker extension to your browser offers considerable improvement for most websites that you visit.

5g infrastructure isn't cheap either, but corporations that profit from the extra junk that they can throw into the bandwidth know that it'll be worth it, so long as we continue accepting such practises. If we for some reason collectively decided that enough is enough, I doubt developing and implementing 5g infrastructure would be a worthwhile investment for the corporations any more.

Confession 2: I was NOT thinking like this CONSCIOUSLY even a year ago, so I was there, too.
Here goes:

Can YOUR phone hurt YOU? That is a question everyone should ask, because it's subjective as hell.
Factors are:
What frequency does YOUR phone emit?

(Depending on the situation, it can work more or less, some ways you can be more so safe and others still dangerous enough, and for you know what that has a metal kind of piece in it, it can reflect the bad stuff from outside but also provide with it's natural resonance frequency, so it's kinda like in gambling where you could win twice as much but you could also lose twice as much. Not that it necessarily goes 100 this way or that way consistently, I'm not even sure how you would do that in such varying conditions or at least for more than 5 seconds straight).
How heavy is it in your area? Are you shielded? If so, how much and how. Back to heavy: Wave riding is REAL, when you jam a signal that's called a CONSISTENT wave ride, wave ride can still happen even if the frequencies are different, think of it as sometimes in sync and sometimes not. Wave riding makes it louder and it can go back and forth in a way which is what I call Wavelength Dominance Shifting and you can demonstrate this with an Electric Keyboard (Musical) that has a reverb function that introduces two other frequencies for the stereo widening effect. If you pay attention, you can feel the Base (you have that, anyway) and two others introduced by widening taking turns in terms of what's dominant.
Your body depending on if you're a Man or Woman (different resonance frequencies, like 10 or 12 - I forget the exact number) will have different reactions depending on the tuning, there's also your diet (temporary items within the body) which also have their natural resonance frequencies, if you eat like crap - it's not gonna be fun, you can basically program your body by what you eat and are exposed to since you can activate different parts of the body depending on how much the waves resonate, for example: As a male: If I keep being exposed to the Venus vibe then my body will have whatever that resonates with that fully and partially be shook more and as a result - start packing things that way. I listen to music on shuffle so I can get my body somewhere so it's not fully predictable and it's one of the reasons why I don't like to blast the sound of a widely viewed live event on TV (I also customize the set to be Black and White so I don't have to dissociate as much in terms of neuro science stuff) since my body will become similar to others and you can probably tell who watched what live event based on their bodies' state shortly and perhaps a little longer after.
Back to what YOUR phone puts out, yes. It could be bad and through programming and how you are (that is subjective) you can induce a crap ton of things, there is NO doubt in my mind about that. Some may resonate with a positive part of your body, such as 528 hz. See this is one of those videos that I just absolutely hate. It's pondering an already defunct idea. These "long term studies" are already complete, in that - we've been blasting radio waves across the globe nonstop for 150 and there has literally never been a single case of someone being injured or damaged because of these said radio waves. Specific one off cases are too much just that - specific. You can't claim general adverse health effects if you have to specify the damage your looking for because at large you can already see that damage isn't widespread and therefore not a generalize heth effect. So those studies looking at time spend watching and electrical intensity and that, are quite pointless. I mean right now there's a huge experiment of this going on. Look at all the YouTubers, who spend 12+ hours a day surrounded by electronics. Literally just compare them to people who spend less than one hour. Are you going to find any general difference between them, that can be attributed not to the fact that they have spend 12+ hours on a computer, in front of a screen, all that jazz - but from them spending 12+ hours surrounded by flowing electrons. The answer - is no. There are no generalized health effects from just spending time in the vicinity of weakly flowing electrons. N.O.N.E. As far as any actual data is concerned the only harmful effects that are even remotely considered is having your phone sit on your bear chest or breast may or may not increase risk of cancer. Your skull is even thick enough to where you can just leave your phone sitting on your head and it won't do anything to your brain. These waves are in no way harmful unless they are localized and directed. the perfect example is the microwave. I'm almost certain there isnt a single documented case of someone getting cancer from their microwave. Because the waves are localized and directed specifically within the microwave, you can stand in front of it and not get cancer - because the waves that come into contact with you are radiated normally and are not directed and concentrated on you. But if you step in the microwave where it's all localized and concentrated and directed towards you, it's not gonna be a fun time. Same with radio waves. Absolutely harmless unless localized and concentrated directly at you. A good example is that military tool that's like a radio wave gun, that's shaped like a spot light and directs concentrated radio waves at a specific target. We KNOW this stuff. Pondering defunct shit like this is why there are people who actually do think 5G towers cause cancer. If there were, we would definitely see it by now. So weakly moving electromagnetic radiation is for general consensus is NOT harmful in any way, and nor is being in the vicinity of electricity/flowing electrons.
PSA: Obviously this is very different than coming into physical contact with said electrons, ie electrocution. That is obviously harmful.

Hacen una pequeña investigación con total ignorancia técnica de las radiaciones no ionizantes cuando provienen de fuentes artificiales. Ahh por cierto, ademas se afirma que los estudios que muestran los efectos nocivos son todos cuestionables porque son subjetivos y se trata de encuestas y cosas así otra vez TOTAL IGNORANCIA. Hay estudios doble ciego realizados en sangre (efecto rouleaux), fragmentación del ADN (15 laboratorios independientes), variabilidad de la frecuencia cardiaca (docenas de universidades e institutos), cambios en la actividad cerebral (otra docena de estudios). Esta gente KURZGESAGT no realizaron una verdadera investigación objetiva. No hablan de los estudios realizados por el NTP(National Toxicology Program) en USA, la FDA, el Proyecto Internacional de Campos Electromagneticos de la OMS, porque no mencionan que los estudios que no consiguen efectos nocivos se realizaron solo en Adultos Hombres de 30 años de edad. No hablan de los miles de estudios realizados a nivel celular sobre efectos de stress oxidativo - radicales libres (especialmente una molécula llamada peroxynitrito) y la consecuencia reacción de inflamación. No tiene idea de los estudios sobre las personas Electro Hipersensibles y los estudios realizados de Diagnostico Diferencial para descartar efecto nocebo. (El efecto nocebo si esta presente en la mitad de las personas con Electro sensibilidad y algunos con problemas psicológicos y ninguna reacción en su cuerpo, pero hay sujetos presentando hipersensibilidad eléctrica a las radiaciones que también presentan hipersensibilidad química y eso no es efecto nocebo). Hay mucha ignorancia en estos videos o hay una idea preconcebida del tema que quiere compartirse sin querer verificar las informaciones.  El Electrosmog es muy controversial y hay una docena de mitos absurdos alrededor del tema, igual que las locas teorías de conspiración de la quinta generación de telecomunicaciones pero eso no convierte al tema en una falacia. El tema es serio y hay quienes si han realizado investigaciones medicas al respecto, grupos de PhD multidisciplinarios quienes han realizado estudios con evidencias claras. Pregunto a KURZGESAGT van a ustedes a hacer otro video contando toda la historia y no lo que es conveniente? Esto demostraría si son o no profesionales.

Just a thought experiment here; if I'm wrong and somebody can (politely) tell me why, I'll happily accept the explanation and move on.

The shorter the wavelength of the radiation, the more harmful it is to organisms. I would guess this is because the shorter the wavelength, the greater the probability is that the radiation will bump into an organic molecule within a given space while passing through an organism and knock out an electron or split an atom. Radio wavelengths are so long that they rarely (but not never) bump into an organic molecule, and because such a collision is so rare the organism can heal quick enough that it never develops into cancer, hence why radio waves are so safe. (Living organisms experience nuclear fission "all the time," but normally the frequency is so low that it's far too negligible to be endangering.)

Now consider a living space packed full of electrical devices, each broadcasting radio waves for wireless network communication in addition to the radiation generated by electric currents. While these devices are each emitting long-wavelength radiation which is normally harmless, this space is saturated with long-wavelength radiation, such that waves are overlapping and crisscrossing, to the degree that some devices even experience radio interference. Similar to how a single thread is weak enough to break by hand but several woven together into a rope are extremely strong, could an extreme saturation of normally harmless long-wavelength radiation be equivalent to exposure to a small dose of short-wavelength radiation? Or is that saturation point so high that it's not likely to be reached in even a Computer House of Internet-Connected Things operating several machines?
Tl;dr biology is difficult to speak conclusively about & much easier to confuse.

Let's do an experiment :

there is a room, inside there is a LED bulb emitting blue light,
you enter the room,
does something bad happen to you ?
Of course not, as we all know, because it's just light.
Light is made of particles called photons.
The photons are here visible.
Let's call them colorful photons.

now, let's decrease the frequency of that blue light,
you enter the room
what do you see ?
you see red light,
red light is blue light of lower frequency.
These are still the same particles, but we decreased the frequency, therefore color changed,
it does absolutely nothing bad to you as we all know,

now let's decrease the frequency again,
you enter the room,
what do you see ?
you see nothing, now, the light is colorless,
once again, these are still the same particles but we decreased the frequency, therefore it became colorless.
These are colorless photons.

--> Now, this colorless light, aka colorless photons, is what cell towers, mobiles and wifi modems emit, this is it :)
--> just like the blue and red light (colorful light), this colorless light does absolutely nothing bad to you
--> we can say that a cell tower emits blue light, with some modifications to it,
the first obvious modification is that the blue color was removed
do you get the nuance ? : there is a blue light, we remove the blue color, we still have light, a colorless light
--> this is the beauty of science : a colorless light that remotely connects devices

Have you experience symptoms such as fatigue, headaches, poor memory, difficulty sleeping, and lack of clarity in your thoughts? It may seem that these could be the results of day-to-day stress and busyness, but there may be another culprit. All of these are symptoms of electro-sensitivity, which is something more and more people are finding themselves affected by. Studies done in 1997 have found “less than a few cases (of electro-sensitivity) per million”, however now as much as 2.5% of the population find themselves affected by electro-sensitivity. Even by most moderate calculations, electro-sensitivity is 1,000 times more common now than it was 20 years ago. Why could this be?

Electro-sensitivity and its symptoms seem to be triggered by certain microwave frequencies of electromagnetic radiation. Microwaves are frequently used in electronics for the purposes of communication between devices. Due to their high frequency, microwaves allow for higher transmission rates and small antenna sizes, which is perfect for high-tech devices that are constantly getting smaller and faster. These are devices such as cell phones, tablets, laptops, and any devices able to connect to Wi-Fi, which can now include TVs and refrigerators

I've known people like this in my life, acquaintances mostly.
One of these people who claimed to suffer from sensitivity to EMR, would have the lights off in the house whenever he was there. There was no wifi.
He lived out in the county, kinda middle of nowhere. Cellphone reception was 1 bar outdoors on a good day, indoors was not functional.
Whenever I came around I had to leave my cellphone in the car (Once I got one anyways).

Work for him was brutal as he had REAL symptoms too that you could see, rashes, panic attacks, the hair on his arms and neck would stand on end, shivers, nausea etc.

He went pretty far too to combat the radiation that he would get exposed to.
He had the utility company hook up service to his garage, which was a decent way from his house, and ran his own illegal (he did it himself, didn't tell utility) line to his house and moved all his stuff (microwave, washer, fridge etc) to that side of the house in a great room. He then disconnected the service feed from the house without telling them and disconnected the electrical lines going to every other part of the house. (He showed me the electrical panel almost all the breakers were off, but he did disconnect some permanently)
This made him feel better, less symptoms, so this was totally a positive reinforcement for him that he was right.


Eventually went on disability. Turned into a real tin foil hatter (literally).
We kinda had a falling out one day after I had read some research that said this stuff doesn't affect people, he just kept pointing to his symptoms as proof that it was the radiation doing it to him.
I had really wanted to prove it to him so without telling him, I turned all his breakers back on in the panel. Well a few weeks later I visited him, and he was telling me he was feeling much better as he had saved up for this ridiculous metal mesh to block the radiation and had lined his bedroom and great room with it. I was so annoyed that he had wasted what little savings he had on some bullshit, I told him what I had done. Obviously he was furious but right before my eyes he started breaking out in a rash, the hair on his neck was standing up, it was freaky. He kept saying "See what it does to me??"
I pointed out to him the obvious; that nothing had changed in that moment except what he THOUGHT was happening to him, that was where his symptoms were coming from, not the EMR.
Didn't matter, he told me to leave and I did, haven't spoken to him since, that was like 10 years ago now.

Now I don't care about those people, you can't help most of them, even when logic and reality are right in front of them.

It surprises me that there doesn't appear to be any serious attempts at studying alleged electrical sensitivity. It would be extremely easy to put a person who claims to be sensitive in a room where you can control the EM fields but provides them know visual or audible information. You could then determine the legitimacy of their claims. If any individual consistently identifies when the fields are turned on then their claim will have been verified.

At the St Louis City Museum there is a very interesting contraption that the public is permitted to use. It measures skin conductivity in milliamps. Fairly simple, right? Well, I made a game out of controlling that. I figured out how to consciously change what number the needle points at. I can't explain how I can do it, but I recorded myself doing it. My running hypothesis is that since anything from skin temperature to the e m fields of your body can change this number it's possible to learn to control these seemingly uncontrollable things with the right effort, but I do wonder if maybe people have a kind of Electro sense. this could explain why some people are sensitive and others are not without it necessarily being a matter of harm.

I'm willing to ascribe some bad effects to EM radiation. The Ganzfeld experiment implies that it can make you hallucinate. And high tension wires can sometimes be associated with paranormal phenomena. I think in those cases though its not paranormal, but the EM messing with people's minds. But I don't think its able to kill you really.

Now Infrasound that I'd be way more worried about. I've gotten headaches from infrasound recordings before. And my dad, a Brown graduate, once told me the story of the "Elevator to Hell." One particular elevator made people riding in it experience headaches, nausea and vomiting. Later on when it was investigated, they discovered that a ventilation fan was just slightly bent out of shape causing it to vibrate on a frequency that made people nauseous.

But infrasound as a weapon has been around since the early 20th century, and its been banned from use by the United Nations. Its even found its way into fiction, part of the way the Reapers in the Mass Effect series brainwash people is by applying infrasound, ultrasound and electromagnetic radiation to people riding inside them.

You forgot to mention that none of the smartphone manufacturers are required to test cell phone radiation while the device is IN DIRECT CONTACT with the test dummy. All of the major smartphones failed to stay below what our government claims is a safe threshold when the devices were tested in direct contact. The government requires only that the devices be tested 5 meters away. I don't think I have ever used my phone  while standing 5 meters from it. Which means I have never used my smart phone in a way that would keep my radiation exposure below "safe levels". This video was quite ignorant in saying definitively that these devices are safe to use. Final thought experiment, what happens when I'm standing in front of my t.v. and ps4, while using my smartphone? Am I still below the safe level when I'm constantly surrounded by radiation emitting devices? And let's be real here, the ones who stand to benefit from lying about health risks are the ones selling the products in question, not the ones expressing concern for potential and valid health concerns from these products. It seems more viable the company who invested a small fortune into a product would lie to mitigate financial losses at the expense amd health risk of it's unknowing customers. You know these videos can't be factually sound and unbiased, or they wouldn't be on YouTube for your viewing pleasure.

Very well said. I must disagree about the screens causing migraines being the placebo effect though. That may well happen sometimes, but there is also the close connection between headaches(of all kinds), and visual, and auditory stimuli. How many people have had the experience of having a headache,  and finding lights, and/or sound make it worse? There are also the factors of muscle tension, stress, and eye strain, all of which may be involved in someone's screen time, depending on the activities.  People may come to premature conclusions about WHY screens cause them headaches,  that doesn't mean there's no connection.

I explain why we have head pain after doing something on computers or mobile phones: the motion of the phone or computer image is based on refreshing at a given frequency. the great strength of science is it's ability to isolate factors... this, for example, is how science overturned the ancient fallacy that heavy things fall more quickly than light things. Galileo created experiments that isolated the factor of mass from the many complicated factors of aerodynamics and turbulence, and disproved the wisdom of the ancient world. He even arrived at a pretty accurate estimate of the gravitational constant. Isolating factors is what lets science see things clearly.
However, I think in this case that science's very strength creates a weakness when trying to assess this risk. Because we don't live in isolation, with just a cell phone, or just one device. Though the cell phone may be the most proximate source of radiation, it is radiating away while we sit in a box veritably humming with different sources of radiation, with neighbors with their own sets of radiation, in towns with centralized higher frequency radiation providing our radio, tv and cell service,. Each of these in isolation is not a problem. Yet I cannot help but think that the superposition of so many electromagnetic waves, cannot help but interfere with one another.
This interference would not form any constant interference pattern, it would be irregular. And with so many sources, it is impossible to predict what might happen. There are simply too many factors for the empirical aspect of science to ever find a satisfactory result. Yet it seems to me that, in such a sea of overlapping waves, occasionally you're going to run into freak little spikes of constructive interference. Sure, it would be incredibly rare, but at a great enough scale, even the exceptionally rare could be significant. And, theoretically, enough superimposed electromagnetic waves could, potentially, cause a spike of a high enough energy to ionize.
And if, say, this random high energy electromagnetic spike happened proximate to a cell at the wrong moment in mitosis, and knocks an electron off an atom or two in one of those little nucleotides, the cell drops a G in the repair, and bam, you've got a mutation, possibly a cancerous one. Yes, this would be incredibly unlikely, but considering that electromagnetic waves are constantly superimposing all around us, the incredibly unlikely might happen more often than we'd like to think.
That being said, I have my cell phone next to me, and I'm not ready to give up electricity and wear a tinfoil hat. Just saying, just because science can't sort it out, doesn't mean it isn't there, it just means it's really really complicated. Science still hasn't figured out turbulence either, but it'll shake your plane when you fly through a cloud.

It's interesting to observe that whenever a lot of studies about a particular topic are made and no evidence for some hypothesis is obtained, people understand it as "hard to prove". While actually the result of those many studies is "the hypothesis is statistically unlikely".
Every study conducted that does not find evidence increases the likelihood that said hypothesis is not true. So if you conducted enough studies and didn't find an evidence you can stop making further studies, because you essentially disproved the hypothesis. Instead however, often people think more studies are necessary - after all you haven't found any evidence yet! Yeah, guess what, maybe that is why there isn't any to find.

Here's what bothers me about all of this: In order to do any scientific research that involves humans, you have to get it cleared by a Human Subject Review Board. And that's a terrific convention that should never, EVER be undermined or even questioned. But the problem is that the voting members of this board are not always -- or even generally -- experts in the specific field. So in order to be sure that they're not approving something that could get them in trouble, they display an innate bias toward research proposals that are being funded by someone else. (Clearly, if something goes wrong, it's the funding source that would stand most immediately accountable, right?) So far so good. But unfortunately these days most of the funding sources, are corporate. So to say, as this video does, that we have "mountains of data" regarding whether exposure to certain types of electromagnetic field are harmful, is at least accidentally misleading. What we have, alas, is "mountains of corporate-funded data" and that's a very different thing to have.

if all our devices are producing radio wave frequencies, that's a lower frequency than visible candle light.
If you're exposed to the light from ONE MILLION CANDLES, would you worry that will "contaminate" you somehow ? because the low frequency produced by our phones and other personal devices is less intense than that. Safety of technology is always worth investigating of course. But I think the main paranoia from some people about radio waves is because it seems mysterious since it's an invisible thing, and because there's a loss of trust that scientific organizations and especially governments will be transparent with the rest of us about any dangers that Are discovered.
I won't dismiss that concern, but I also wouldn't take that possibility of epic conspiracies and ASSUME the very worst speculation is the truth. Sometimes us laypeople just don't know.
We Have to rely on experts in various fields, because that's a better bet than trusting our friends' and internet guru's opinions on every subject out there.
We just need to better ensure ethical accountability for the scientists and other experts we depend on for our health and safety and informed decisions, so that we may feel more confidence in the reliability of those who are accredited as experts.

A study on the damaging effects of an electromagnetic wave below ultraviolet being harmful is almost always going to turn up saying it isn't. Certain parts of your body are much more sensitive to it (like your eyes) but even still it takes a considerable amount of energy for waves below ultraviolet to be damaging to you. A tragic example I read about detailing exactly how quickly damaging microwave radiation can be to a human body actually sourced an article where a mother put her human baby in a microwave oven. It's terrible, but the autopsy of this atrocity very clearly indicated that microwaves, the same frequency that your cellphones, routers, and misc wireless devices operate at, do not penetrate deeply into your skin even with considerable amounts of power, because the infant didn't suffer deep burns even after several minutes in the appliance. Another example is microwave tethers which workers who would typically install them on poles would use as a source of warmth for their hands when installing them on cold days. These tethers operate at power levels up to hundreds of times more than that of a meager cellphone with it's couple mile 600MHz RF.  Bottom line is if it has a lot of power it'll probably have signs that say don't touch or get in the way of the device, I work in front of satellites that operate in the 7GHz range daily and despite my coworkers being absolutely petrified at the idea of me being in front of it while it's transmitting there's not really a substantial risk due to low exposure time and relatively meager amounts of power.

FINALLY! Someone admits there MIGHT be some negative health effects caused by electronics. Last year I started having seizures, and in addition to that I would have extreme shooting pains whenever I was in physical contact with any electronics. I am aware of placebo/nocebo effects, but this happened even when I wasn't aware that I had my phone on me, or if it was on or not. For example, I was at school and I always have my phone turned off and in my bag. I forgot I left it on and put it in my pocket and was having shooting pains in that leg. I could only use my computer while wearing 2 pairs of gloves but eventually i started having reactions to that too.

I'm not saying my condition was initially caused by these electronics or that this could affect anyone. I believe whatever caused my seizures also lowered the reactive threshold of my nerves to the point where even the weakest electromagnetic fields would give me symptoms. I was already being treated like I was faking my unrelated seizures so I was frustrated that I couldn't explain my shooting pain symptoms without seeming like a maniac.

0:35 I hate to be that guy, but it's who I am, and a photon is not a charged particle. It's implied here that moving electrons create the same electromagnetic waves which define a photon.


To be annoyingly specific: It is true that the motion of charge creates a magnetic field (Biot-Savart Law), but the motion does not create an electric field. The mere prescence of a charge creates an electric field. Motion of charge does not. It is true that a changing magnetic field creates an electric field (Faraday's Law), but the magnetic field does not change merely with a moving charge. This generally happens with inductors.

It may seem like I'm missing the point, but it's important to establish the difference between radiation (photons) and electricity (light) for the purpose of this video.

Symptoms subsided when the residents left the area, often to stay with family and thus evade their suffering. At a public meeting with the afflicted locals, the tower's owners pledged to switch off the mast immediately to assess whether it was responsible for their ailments. is that, even longer wavelengths can be harmful, in excessive amounts...

Yes, the wavelengths have to resonate with what they're going to affect, due to quantum physics;
however, that doesn't mean that one photon, is able to heat your dinner, alone.

The body works bioelectrically, there is even a barely noticable function for orientation that works on the magnetic field of the earth, which is especially developed on many birds.
Inducing currents can definitely mess with that on some level. I have read several reports of birds having more and more trouble navigating over populated areas, but I can't check their validity.

There are other aspects to electrical devices that might have more effect than em or rf, mainly sound and light. Many components, even just wire couplings, can emit noise on various frequencies, often barely hearable, which can effect our sleep. I have experienced this personally and it made life unbearable. Also the smallest led's can lighten up a room so much we have more trouble sleeping. And devices with a visual interface usually strain the eyes, and consumption and processing of information can make us more tired too.

It seems to me that extreme cases of sensitivity should be very easy to prove or disprove. For example, some individuals claim to be allergic to common EM fields. This is typically dismissed as psychosis, but if a person truly have this level of sensitivity all you would need to do is to place them in a room where they are unable to see when the field is turned on or off and to be asked to make a hand gesture if and when a field is generated. To my knowledge no one is ever even attempted this.

The nocebo effect is very easy to establish in a case like this because the fields are easy to control.

In my case, I can actually feel it when certain fields are present, but it's nothing so dramatic. I can't feel a Wi-Fi network, but I can feel when a CRT television turns on or when air conditioner turns on or off. I've tested this with a detector and found that during such times the lines in the house actually give off significantly more EMFs, and in fact in some old houses the lights can flicker when an air conditioner kicks on or off.

Rather than testing whether these fields are harmful or not, it should be easier to establish whether or not a person can perceive such Fields consciously. If they can be perceived consciously that it would give us a starting point to establish whether or not they are safe. In all likelihood, safe levels might even vary by the individual.

Also it is recommended that your router is put a few meters away from people in the manual, it's not the electromagnetic radiation, but the radio waves that it is perhaps best not to sit next to.

The problem is that there aren’t any long term studies regarding electromagnetic smog from cell phones. Obviously because the “smartphone revolution” only began about ten years ago. So nobody can actually know and be absolutely certain about what happens to your body if you carry a smartphone on you for lets say 40 years. Could men become impotent? Could it be harmful for a pregnancy? Is calling and pressing your phone against the head causing brain tumours? Nobody can tell you that until a certain amount of time has passed to get meaningful study results.
It’s a difficult topic as this concerns almost everyone’s life, the desire to stay always connected and being up to date.
But if that uncertainty is enough reason for you to be a little bit more cautious about using your cellphone, here are some tips:
- put your phone in flight mode while you’re sleeping
- try to call somebody while using headphones, put on speakers
- put your smartphone not next to you if you don’t need it
- avoid Bluetooth
- do your own critical research on the topic
Have a nice day!

I'm sorry for such an off-topic comment, but I think the idea that we leave trails of passwords online is wrong, because password fields don't usually allow to copy text from them. This would be valid if a person unknowingly visited phishing sites, but usually they are avoidable. Also, even when using a password manager like Dashlane, a person can still accidentally store some passwords insecurely, reducing the effectiveness of the password protection. Also, a password manager doesn't protect a person from leaking personal data to the internet; that is up to them not to share it and the services not to disclose it, either accidentally or on purpose. For these reasons, I think that the Dashlane advertisement was misleading and @Kurzgesagt should have been more clear about how password managers work.

2:50 in: just because they don't know what the mechanism is, doesn't mean they're wrong. They were studying correlation, which isn't the same as causation, but it's also downright idiotic to take ignore. If people are getting brain cancer on the side of their head that they use cellphones with, then, I frankly don't give a fuck if their reporting on usage frequency was "reliable". They know which side of their head they use the phone, any other information, is a red - herring.

The problem with scientific paradigms is that once groupthink takes over, you have to FORCE the community to acknowledge something. And at this point, doing your own study isn't enough. Either you have a 15 million dollar study and are a career scientist, or you have no voice. This is why science is viewed as a cult, it has a long history of officially determining things are safe, like putting lead in gasoline, THEN fighting the people who oppose them, THEN, pretending science is still pure.

Obviously we're onto something in regards to actually studying and measuring things. But everything else surrounding that, especially the governance element, is broken.

For instance, Kurzgesagt's happy to essentially tell us the 5G network will be totally safe. But even if it was, that itself is another red-herring, because the even more disturbing danger is the information dragnet it will create. Having a truly impenetrable iron fist used to be technologically impossible, but now your every, step, will be tracked. I doubt encryption and VPNs will mean anything when the ISP you pay for is reporting any signal you sent or receive. What do you think happens next?

For me personally, fatigue, headaches and other problems that show a connection between my usage of electronics and my health have likely more to do with the amount of stimuli my senses are receiving than what the electromagnetic radiation might be doing. I get the same problem if it's dark out and there's candle flames, light bulbs or other primary light sources in my direct view. Considering that any screen is essentially a large collection of primary light sources, rather than indirect reflections, that's a lot of stimuli to process. The result is that I end up feeling irritated and fatigued by them if there isn't sufficient ambient light to help balance it out. This is a common thing, so keep it in mind.

I don’t think we have the evidence right now to support the conclusion that the effects of electromagnetic pollution are below a measurable threshold.

For example, Transcranial electromagnetic stimulation techniques are used by neurologists to cause firing in the brain. The magnetic potentials used are 2-3 teslas, but a much lower signal could certainly stimulate nerves outside of the skull, like spinal or thoracic parts of your nervous system.

We also don’t know how many microstructures in the body are actually acting as antennae for specific frequencies. This is certainly an avenue for the transfer of energy into the body. It would also explain why there are relatively few “sensitive” individuals, because each persons antennae microstructure and EMF exposure are unique.

I think that pain research in particular illustrates how seemingly innocuous influences can accumulate into a significant impact to quality of life. Chronic and unexplained pain can develop from a set of minor injuries.

I also think that people turning off their home wifi occasionally and wanting fewer gadgets also leads to a host of other benefits.

It's gotten genuinely disappointing how increasingly little effort goes into these advertisements being any kind of forthright, when I've always considered these videos to be trustworthy and of a higher quality, in production as well, but moreso in information. Providing nuggets of knowledge in layman's terms but respectfully and without being condescending.

'Don't worry about electro smog, but hey hard transition into the dangers of the internet! Use this code for this password service "Because We Want You To Have Nice Things"'. And not because you make money off of us using your affiliate code? I realize this probably seems nitpicky but it's recurring; when it comes to how you guys keep trying to sell things, it tends to just shift abruptly into being shady, like a feigned covert effort, but it's not subtle and it's not honest or respectful.

In a gross kind of irony, it's actually the same type of information that I can see this channel making videos on wherein you call out lies and a manipulation using methods that prey upon a populace, proven to be influential. The dignity and high moral fiber that the channel tries to otherwise uphold just takes a back seat. It's been more frequently noticeable and obvious, I assume as the channel is growing and things are being handled by marketing teams or something that weren't initially there and are apathetic to the scruples this channel had exuded to uphold, or the ownership has just gotten greedier, who knows. It's apparent, whatever it is.

This video is at odds. When you make a vid that specifically calls attention to seeing past misinformation published and spread for personal motive, and then railroad that very same video into your advertising and do the exact same thing in trying to sell things to your viewers, it makes your whole channel look cheap, low quality, and more difficult to trust. The very basis of this series is the thing you most directly oppose by treating your viewers like nothing but dumb consumers and it's getting increasingly worse. There's nothing wrong with monetizing and profiting from these videos, but you have a choice in how you do so and how you market all this stuff. Treat us with a little dignity; I legitimately think the viewers of a channel like this would be more receptive to that anyway. ... didn't intend to write this much, but, spontaneous internet rant novella done.

My headaches are because I absorb huge amounts of information at once when I'm on my computer all day.
My nausea is caused by my unhealthy diet, due to my reluctance to get off my computer and make a proper meal.

My exhaustion is because I'm in bad shape. I'm the type to use a computer or phone often, and just laying or sitting motionless. I have little stamina and so, I get tired easily.

1:00 Here you're referring to black body radiation which is not the reason why a radiator gives off heat. Heat is defined as a flow of energy between two bodies cause by a difference in their temperatures, this is what's know as "conduction heat transfer". Black body radiation is a different phenomenon entirely, it only involves one body and it gives off EM radiation (usually infrared light in our experiences) based on that one body's temperature, independant of its environment. BBR is not heat.
I know it's only tangential to the video but it's important to point out inaccuracies so your videos can become even better.


Edit:
2:20 Again, it's a misconception that heat is transfered as infrared radiation. It's actually the other way around: just because you have temperature you are radiating infrared light. Radiated light crosses into the visible spectrum at about 500°C, that's why molten metal glows, in fact everything is glowing all the time but our eyes only see a certain spectrum of wavelengths. There is nothing special about infrared or visible light, it's just the tuning evolution gave to our human eyes. Visible light can heat as much if not more than infrared, because higher frequency means more energy.

Hey, generally love your channel, but one slight inaccuracy - the animation of the food being heating the microwave implies that microwaves heat things from the center out - but this is a myth, and a source of some hysteria relevant to this video. They heat from the outside in - it would take a collumated beam and low absorption for them to heat from the inside out, and microwaves have neither. The exception to this is where you have a food that consist of something that absorbs microwaves effectively wrapped in something that doesn't, but t doesn't really look like that is what your animation is showing. Minor nitpick in a generally good video though

Slight misconception: electricity is not same as electromagnetic radiation. Yes, EM is caused by alternating current (but no DC), but it's no entirely correct to use them as synonyms. That is sentences - electricity is harnless isn't it with the same meaning as EM is harmless, because those are 2 different physical things.

Like if i have 600V battery (like in electric cars) and i touch it's terminals, i will certainly die. But this DC current will make no EM radiation, as only changing current (in time) creates changing magnetic fields = electromagnetic radiation.

Also what you forget to mention, is that while in lower frequencies EM doesn't do ionising damage, EM energy is absorbed as heat. Until certain power level that is no problem, but with high enough intensity non-ionising will also do damge, though not directly from radiation, but from absorbec heat energy.
Good example is Lasers. They emmit same harmless EM that we get from the Sun, but with much hihger intensity, so sight that it can really burn your skin.
Same could apply in lower frequencies as well, that excess absobed heat in tissue causes damage (Because proteins break down in high enough heat) . Luckily that there are regulations for this (SAR), which keeps everything in safe power levels.

Also what keeps "all" (radio) EM safe is that EM power decreases proportional to 1/(r^2). Thats why the signal power you phone receives from tower is measured in nano or pico wats.

So mostly EM is safe, as long as you don't stick your head in microwave owen.

It's all about the energy of the photons that make up said radiation, and whether it's enough to ionize or not. Any radiation below infra-red carries so little energy density that it cannot ionize most molecules. As for radio waves, the photons carry so little energy they cannot ionize anything at all.


The most they could do is heat something in the same way as a microwave would, by producing a very high amount of photons which agitates the atoms. You would feel this in the form of heat, which of course you don't because there's nowhere near enough radio waves for that to happen. It will not give you cancer, as it physically can't destroy your DNA (aka ionize the atoms that make up your DNA) the same way UV light can, just like a microwaves.


If you stick your hand in a microwave, the most you will get is burns, not a chance you'll get cancer. Radio is even weaker than that, so there it is, case closed.

2:12 - Kurzgesagt once again showing their scientific incompetence. You check your script with real scientists? I don't think so. That passage would be correct if you remove the "infrared" word from it.
The majority of the Sun energy is released as visible "white" light radiation. You can and do get warm by the visible Sun light. The Sun does emit infrared light, but it definitely is not the only one warming you.
We associate infrared light with warmth because it is the wave-length that object/bodies close to room temperature emit.

This little detail is very important when you have to explain the green house effect of CO2. You see, CO2 is completely transparent for visible light, but it captures the infrared light.
So the visible light from the Sun passes on its way down to Earth freely, but then the objects warm up and start emitting more infrared light. That infrared light is captured by the atmospheric CO2 and is kept there, instead of letting it go away into space.
